title: Understanding LinkedIn's Business Model | Revenue streams | Microsoft Acquisition & Road ahead
author: Pavan Sathiraju

key_facts: LinkedIn was acquired by Microsoft in 2016.
LinkedIn has over 750 million users worldwide.
LinkedIn is the only major social media platform where users pay for premium services.
Microsoft integrates LinkedIn with Outlook and other professional tools.
LinkedIn's revenue streams include subscriptions, marketing, hiring, learning, and sales.
LinkedIn learning recommends courses based on user skill gaps.
LinkedIn's job postings are significantly fewer than those on Indeed.
LinkedIn is transitioning out of China’s social networking and feed services.
LinkedIn offers an 'Apply with LinkedIn' button for job applications.
LinkedIn profiles may be used by employers to evaluate candidates.
LinkedIn users can express views on academic and industry topics.
LinkedIn's integration with Microsoft products enhances workplace productivity.
LinkedIn's professional network is unique among social platforms.
LinkedIn's revenue growth rate is 25% year over year.
LinkedIn's marketing revenue reaches up to $3 billion annually.
key_opinions: LinkedIn's ability to charge users makes it unique among social platforms.
Microsoft's acquisition of LinkedIn was a strategic match made in heaven.
Maintaining a strong LinkedIn profile is essential for young professionals.
Negative comments on LinkedIn can harm one’s professional reputation.
LinkedIn's future potential lies in smart contracts and AI-driven recommendations.
LinkedIn's expansion into education for students could be transformative.
The platform's integration with Microsoft tools benefits both users and employers.
LinkedIn's revenue streams are still small compared to competitors like Google and Facebook.
Employers may eventually require LinkedIn profiles as part of hiring processes.
LinkedIn's future growth is promising despite current scale limitations.
LinkedIn's current features are already beneficial but more innovation is needed.
The platform's value will increase as it becomes central to professional identity.
LinkedIn's niche focus on professionals gives it long-term competitive advantage.
LinkedIn's future success depends on deeper integration with enterprise workflows.
LinkedIn's global reach is limited by its exit from China's social media market.
key_datapoints: Revenue growth rate: 25% year over year
39% of LinkedIn subscribers are premium members
LinkedIn marketing revenue: up to $3 billion annually
Indeed posts approximately 25 million jobs per month
LinkedIn posts 2–3 million jobs per month
LinkedIn has 750 million+ users across professional networks
LinkedIn learning recommends 3–4 courses for new hires on average
LinkedIn’s acquisition price by Microsoft: $26.2 billion (implied context)
LinkedIn’s 'Apply with LinkedIn' button is already implemented
LinkedIn’s China exit occurred within the last 3–4 months
LinkedIn’s integration with Microsoft Outlook is already active
LinkedIn’s professional content is used to assess emotional and analytical strengths
LinkedIn’s course recommendations are based on skill gap analysis
LinkedIn’s future smart contract system requires three successful conversations
